GOVERNOR'S ADDRESS

Debate on the Address
(Second Day)


    Order read for resuming adjourned debate on Question [5th September],

    "That this Assembly expresses its thanks to His Excellency the Governor for his Address delivered on Wednesday, 29th August, 1956." - (The Chief Minister).

    Question again proposed.

Column: 109



    Mr M. P. D. Nair (Seletar): Sir, I was saying yesterday that the Rent Control Ordinance, as it stands at the moment, does not afford adequate protection to the farmers who are termed as squatters. Sir, I am aware that this is not a debate on the Rent Control Ordinance but I thought perhaps it would be a good thing if I dealt with the question of exploitation which is prevalent in Singapore and which is referred to in paragraph 7 of the Governor's Address.

    Sir, due to the state of housing development in the rural areas, many of the farmers are being exploited by the landlords. They say that these farmers are not tenants. They are only allowed to stay on their lands and if the landlords want to get rid of them, they are at liberty to do so. The Rent Control Ordinance has not been very helpful in this respect. The Rent Control Ordinance is not applicable to houses that have been built after 1947, and even in respect of those houses built prior to 1947, the landlords could evict them by giving them one year's notice, or if they (landlords) have plans of a new layout approved by the Singapore Improvement Trust or a building authority, they can get these tenants out. It is true, Sir, that the courts are given a certain amount of discretion in the matter, but as I see it, the courts themselves are completely helpless.

    Sir, the manner in which dealings take place between the landlord and the tenant is very peculiar. I have here a bundle of notices which have been issued to squatters in my own constituency. The improvements that have been made on the land by the tenant also arouse serious difficulty for the tenant. For the information of this Assembly, Sir,I shall read out the type of letters which, written in a most reprehensible way, are being sent out to the occupiers of land. I will not mention the name of the landlord, nor am I willing to give the name of the tenant. The letter says:

    "This letter serves to inform you that the company now requires to use this land and you are requested to remove the crops and trees from the area. If you fail to do so, the said crops and trees will be destroyed."

Column: 110

Sir, efforts have been made in the past by the landlords to bulldoze the crops and trees, irrespective of whether or not the tenant derives his income from these crops. Sir, it would appear that the Rent Control Ordinance does not try to establish the necessary relations between the landlord and the tenant. It appears to me that this Ordinance was enacted at a time when landlords wanted to increase their rents and at the moment it helps in this way - that if the landlord wishes to raise his rents, he can do so under certain provisions of this Ordinance. Recovery of possession also appears to be a very easy matter these days. I would suggest that the relationship between the tenant and the landlord should receive the immediate attention of the Government.

    I do not think for a moment that any minor amendments to the Rent Control Ordinance can solve the problem. What we need in Singapore today is protection for the tenants, particularly the farmers and cultivators who are undergoing this hardship. I have been able to sort out some of the difficulties by the use of tact and diplomacy. I wonder how long I can go on begging the landlord to have leniency shown to them. I think it is high time that the State steps in and introduces some legislation specifying the relationship between the landlord and the tenant.

    I now come to the land problem. In Singapore today there are many "landlords" who hold 999-year leases. I understand that 999-year leases are of various types. There are some which are given purely and simply for agricultural purposes, and if the landlords holding this type of lease want to make use of the land for any other purposes, then they will have to approach the Crown for permission to do so. There are, of course, very many areas of land today which have been leased by the Crown to people on 999-year leases. These people have been paying very little to the Government in the way of T.O.L. fees. The situation now is that these landlords are selling their lands which belong to the people. All these lands once belonged to the people and

Column: 111

they have been leased out to these landlords for a specific purpose. Therefore, if a man has, say, a hundred acres of land on a 999-year lease and he is not utilising it for agricultural purposes, the land must be reverted back to the Government who can make use of it for the benefit of the people. Sir, it is time that an examination of all these 999-year leases be made and if the land is not being made use of for the benefit of the public, then it should revert back to the Crown. In this way there will be a considerable extent of land available to Government for public purposes, such as housing, and if the Government is unable to put up buildings on its own, then the land should be distributed to individuals who could put up their own houses.

    Take the case of T.O.L. land. Many years ago people approached the Government for pieces of land and the position today is that there are people holding more than 40 acres of land for their own purposes and on that land are hundreds of people who are paying rents to the T.O.L. holders. I think the position is very unsatisfactory. I also suggest that a revision of all T.O.L. land be made and that the land be allotted to the people according to their needs. If a person has ten people in the family, then the land allotted to him should be in accordance with that number.

    Sir, I would like to turn now to rural housing. I am sure the Government has made an honest and sincere attempt at alleviating the living conditions of the rural people. An example of that is the housing project in Bukit Panjang where the Government intends to build low-cost houses. But I think more improvements should be made in the rural areas. It strikes me as curious that whereas the Government is making an effort to build houses in order to clear slums in the city area, a corresponding effort to help farmers and fishermen in the rural areas is absent. Sir, I am not saying this as a criticism of the Government but I am just placing these proposals before the Assembly so that at a later date they can be examined. There are thousands of old houses - houses 30 years old - in the rural areas belonging to the farmers and

Column: 112

fishermen. These people cannot possibly find money to repair and keep them in good condition, and the Government is unable to help them. I think, Sir, in the interests of farming and fishing, we must do something more to help these people earn a good living. The Government should consider giving them outright grants to help them repair and maintain their houses in good condition, so that they could live a decent life and do their work more efficiently. This would help to increase production and create a happy state of affairs for all of us.

    Another subject that I would like to touch upon is the question of poultry inoculation in the rural areas. Representations were made to me a few days ago asking whether I could do something about this proposition. At the moment, farmers in the rural areas find it extremely difficult to come to town and inoculate their poultry. It has been suggested to me that a new system may be adopted by Government; of licensing all large-scale poultry farmers and supplying them with vaccines at reasonable cost, so that they themselves could inoculate their own livestock at their convenience. It is very difficult these days to bring poultry 6 or 7 miles away in the rural areas to a centre in town, queue up and wait for your poultry to be inoculated.

    Sir, there is another aspect of the rural problem that I wish to place before this Assembly. There are various development schemes which have been undertaken by the Government and which hitherto have not brought any results. We hope that these development schemes, efforts by individual departments, could be co-ordinated so that there would be more efficiency. I am thinking of a Rural Development Council under the chairmanship of the Minister for Local Government, Lands and Housing, the members of this Council to be drawn from the departments concerned, such as Agriculture, Fisheries, Education, the City Council, District Councils, the Singapore Improvement Trust and so on. Sir, the rural problem may look curious, but if you analyse it, you will find that it can only be solved if there is more coordination among the

Column: 113

various departments of the Government. I feel sure that Government will examine this problem in the light of what I have said and set up machinery to expedite rural development.

    Sir, I would like now to touch upon a subject which at first I thought I should not do, but I felt I would be failing in my duty if I did not bring it to the notice of this Assembly. So much has been said about multi-lingualism in Singapore and the formulation of an educational system which will nurse all languages. There are English secondary schools, Chinese high schools and there are proposals for Malay secondary schools. But I do not know whether I am correct in saying that there is no Government proposal to establish a Tamil secondary school. As we all know, there is a Chair in the University of Malaya for Tamil and at the moment there is a very wide gap between the primary Tamil school and the University. I hope and believe this gap will be bridged by Government building some Tamil secondary schools.

    Then there is this question of Singapore's unity with the Federation. At first I thought I should not touch on this subject but I now feel that I should have a crack at it. Much has been said about Singapore's unity with the Federation and I look at the problem this way. We must, at this transitional period of our own political development and the political development that is going on outside Singapore, exercise tolerance and diplomacy of the highest order. If we believe that we can shape the political destiny of another territory by exhortation from our own plane, we will find great difficulty in adjusting our differences later on. I would crave the indulgence of this House and ask it to accept the Chief Minister's way of approach for unity with the Federation.

    There is yet another problem, the question of external relations with countries like Australia, Britain and the United States. I believe, Sir, that an external affairs policy depends on a sound internal policy and again at this transitional period we must develop tolerance within our own territory. It may be that unknowingly we might have a student theme on foreign policy, but then we

Column: 114

are not writing a political thesis in order to get a political diploma. I do hope that in all our endeavours to work out a foreign policy we will not forget our own home first. This is an era of international politics. This is an era of international co-operation, and I hope the Assembly will shape a foreign policy based on our own internal policy.

    Mr G. A. P. Sutherland (Nominated): Mr Speaker, Sir, yesterday in introducing his motion the Chief Minister asked for criticism and particularly in two speeches, those of the Member for Serangoon and of the Member for Tanjong Pagar, he got what he asked for. The points made by the Member for Serangoon were brushed aside by the Member for Tanjong Pagar as so many trivialities. Then the hon. Member proceeded to deal at length, especially at length, with the inadequacies, the inanities, the omissions and the generalities of His Excellency the Governor's Address. Sir, no one could accuse the Member for Tanjong Pagar of being a dull speaker and he is frequently very entertaining indeed, though, of course, some of us, as we grow accustomed to his forensic style, are perhaps not quite so impressed by what he has to say as we were in the earlier days of the Assembly. Yesterday he ran very true to form. I expected him to lick his chops over the situation in Suez and was not disappointed.

    I was amused at his succinct definition of "Independent" as seen through the eyes of the Chinese, and I am sure he could produce a much funnier one for the nominated Independents, but I would rather not hear it.

    I had previously determined not to take part in this debate - "intervention" is the word the Member for Cairnhill (Mr Marshall) called it - but you will recall, Sir, that the ex-Chief Minister promoted me through a series of grades to become the representative of British capital in this Assembly, and as capital was touched on several times yesterday I must, of course, watch my interests. The Member for Serangoon said that there had been a considerable flight of capital from Singapore. In my view,

Column: 115

the reports of flight of capital from Singapore have been grossly exaggerated. It is, of course, true that there may be some people in this country who have not the faith in its future that many of its elected Members have, but I can assure hon. Members that a great deal of the capital which indeed has left this country in recent months has done so on a temporary basis, seeking to take advantage of the capital markets in the City of London where interest rates are high. This is quite a normal movement.

    Then the Member for Tanjong Pagar told us how worried the heads of big business in London were about the future of their capital stake in this country. Well, they will be more worried if they read the full text of his speech and if they think his Party is ever likely to come into power. Sir, one can make anything sound silly by reading it aloud rapidly, laying false emphasis and dismissing the whole thing by chucking it on the table and saying it is all balderdash. But I think paragraph 4 of the Governor's Address is good, especially when it speaks of "a need to import capital and, consequently, to attract foreign investment". Does the People's Action Party think this is nonsense, or are they unable to dissociate capital from colonialism? If you cannot produce or create sufficient capital for your needs and if you cannot raise it locally, you have to import it. The goal of successful industrialisation of this country is a long way off and all the skill and technical know-how that would eventually help to create capital would take time to build up. Thereafter local industries would have to be highly competitive to compete with the vast concerns of Western Europe. This competition is actually being experienced at this moment and I think the Member for Paya Lebar had something yesterday when he suggested, I think, the introduction of some modified form of protection. [Interruption.] It is interesting to note, Sir, that we heard the Member for Tanjong Pagar for 2½ hours without interrupting him but he just cannot keep quiet when others are

Column: 116

speaking. So I think, Sir, it is most injudicious to discourage the foreign investor with wild talk of what will happen to the future of capital in Malaya. What in any case is wrong with capital earning dividends, especially when Government collects 30 per cent of the remitted rewards in any case?

    The Member for Tanjong Pagar's attack on the Government policy as delineated in His Excellency's Address consisted chiefly in complaining of the absence of facts and figures and that it was all rather airy-fairy and vague. My first reaction to the Address was that it was rather good, but since I listened to it being torn to bits I have come to the conclusion that it was even better, I think it was rather clever of Government to present it in the way they did, thus preventing the Opposition from indulging in any specific attack. The Member for Tanjong Pagar complained that there was nothing in it that he could get his teeth into, or words to that effect. In the circumstances, of course, he was obliged to use the vehicle of ridicule, a vehicle, of course, that can be all too easily over-loaded.

    Sir, I personally have no axe to grind, or perhaps only a very tiny one, and I do not propose to comment in detail on His Excellency's Address which one journalist of international repute described as containing everything but the kitchen sink! I think perhaps it might have been more apposite and topical if he had said, instead, the gas cooker! But may I, Sir, as a humdrum bank manager, say that paragraph 33 of the Address strikes the right note? Unlike the Member for Tanjong Pagar who castigated Government for a lack of figures, I am satisfied that Singapore's finances are indeed in sound shape. Where there is a will, there is a way. If Government intends, as it states, that nothing shall be done to shake the confidence and the stability of Singapore's economy and currency, then the Government will have the support of all ranks, from the daily wage-earners to the rubber barons.

    Mr Lee Kuan Yew: And the bankers.

Column: 117



    Mr Sutherland: Naturally I am in between! Many hon. Members will have had the experience of the frightful things that can happen when you have a debased currency, for instance, in the Japanese occupation. I myself had that experience, and I also had the experience of seeing the Chinese national dollar depreciate in geometric progression in post-war China, and have seen the peculiar immorality that inflation like that brings about. It is significant to note, Sir, that two currencies survived the Japanese holocaust - survived intact, both colonial currencies - the Hongkong dollar and the Straits dollar, because they were backed 100 per cent.

    Sir, as I have said, I do not intend to comment in detail on His Excellency's Address. The leaders of the two Opposition Parties have done so, and one of them complained of the paucity of facts contained therein. If every paragraph were boosted up with facts and figures to the extent desired, it would be as long as the Colony's Annual Report and goodness knows how long the Opposition speeches would have been; and if the group of Independents all gave it a detailed analysis, then I reckon that this sitting would last longer than the Budget sitting!

    To return, Sir, for just a moment to the position of the nominated Members. It is, after all, in this outmoded and anachronistic constitution, as indeed in every other, the votes that count, and the votes of the nominated Members on this side of the House could today have been of almost historic importance. In the event, it would appear that that will not be necessary and that face will be saved all-round.

    Mr Lee Kuan Yew (Tanjong Pagar): What a shame!

    Mr Sutherland: However, we are not Government yes-men. Even the ex-Chief Minister realised that when he hurled his invective at us, or commended us for our statesmanlike behaviour, depending on whether we opposed or supported his policy. For my own part, I vote according to my views and conscience and with due

Column: 118

regard for certain loyalties. I will be extremely vocal against Government should the situation so warrant, a privilege denied to my ex-officio compatriots, bless their hearts!

    Finally, Sir, my view on the speed at which this Colony should proceed to self-government has not changed, but I am prepared to support this motion wholeheartedly and to give the Chief Minister his vote of confidence. One way of looking at it, Sir, might be - and I do not mean it too cynically - if you will permit the phrase, that the Labour Front Coalition Government is the devil we know, a devil whose demoniacal forces have been, to some extent, modified.

    Mr Goh Tong Liang (Bukit Panjang): Mr Speaker, Sir, I see that the Government attaches much importance to the encouragement and expansion of agricultural production and says, further on in the Governor's Address, that it will do this and do that to help the farmers. That is all very well, but they can be promises that will take a long time to fulfil. I think it would be very much better for the Government now to examine all the outstanding grievances and hardships of the farmers. If the Government really intends to encourage pig breeding, the first thing they should do is to do away with the pig-sty licence fees. The amount is small - only $6 a year - but the pig breeders consider that it is an imposition to restrict pig breeding. That is one of their grievances. Whenever they want to build or repair their huts, they have had to undergo considerable difficulty. They cannot improve the condition of their huts by changing from attap to corrugated iron sheets. They find great difficulty in sending for their wives and children from China to help them on their farms. There has been so much trouble in getting their pigs and poultry inoculated. In many cases they complain that their farmland is too small. The 30-year lease is too short. Bad roads give them a lot of trouble and affect their profit.

    Now we come to their hardships. Last year an epidemic of swine fever, or whatever it is called, wiped out some $200,000 worth of pigs and piglings in

Column: 119

my division alone. The farmers got very little help or no help at all from the Veterinary Department. In 1954 the price of pigs was about $90 per picul and the cost of bran was about $10 a picul. From the beginning of 1955 down to the present day, the price of pigs has gone down to $75 per picul but the cost of bran has gone up to $15 a picul. This imbalance in the prices, coupled with the loss through the epidemic last year, has sent many farmers to the verge of bankruptcy. Pigs and fowls are still dying, although not at the same alarming rate as last year's. I think very soon we may have a shortage of local pork if no action is taken.

    In the case of fishermen, the hardest hit are the Malay fishermen living along the Straits of Johore, due to the curfew. These people are in my division. Even in the pre-curfew days they could hardly make ends meet. What is their plight now without the means of fishing in the Straits of Johore? I hope Government will quickly look into the matter, and if my services are required, I shall be only too glad to help.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, throughout the 62 paragraphs of the Governor's Address, there is no mention of electricity, one of the essential services for mankind. I hope that the Government has plans to supply electricity as widely as possible to the rural areas and that it was only through inadvertence that it was not incorporated in the Governor's Address.

    Lastly, I hope that the points I have brought out about pigs and fowls dying, the high cost of animal feed, fishermen in dire straits, are not petty things, and if the Member for Tanjong Pagar thinks they are, I invite him to tell his constituents about them.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, in spite of all I have said, I wholeheartedly support the Government policy.

    Mr William Tan (Tiong Bahru): Mr Speaker, Sir, His Excellency's Address just happened to draw our attention to the fact that Government has been paying only lip service during the last 17 months particularly to the urgent need to stimulate the entrepot trade of Singapore with our neighbours, Indonesia and the Federation of Malaya. Well, we have seen

Column: 120

what had happened before to the last trade mission to Indonesia. After a lot of fanfare and publicity, the Marshall led trade mission, which was described by Labour Fronters as a triumphant one, had not produced a single concrete result. The much-vaunted relaxations of export controls from Indonesia of rubber slabs have not materialised and instead of more rubber coming in from Indonesia to feed our rubber milling industry, there is actually less import of rubber slabs. The beautiful dream of the Labour Front Coalition Government of providing more work for the people in this industry has not been realised. It remains just a beautiful dream. There is, in fact, more unemployment. The queue is increasing every day and what has the new Labour Coalition Government done during the last three months to improve the situation?

    There is no influx of capital, no new industry has been planned, and there is a diminishing national income. What we were given during the last 17 months were just promises and mere lip service. And now Government recognises the need to import or attract capital, but is it just wishful thinking in the light of what has happened? No local or foreign capital will be attracted here unless the Government can produce a "stable political climate", and gain the confidence of the local or foreign investors.

    A series of strikes, fanned by irresponsible political agitators and parasites, and with no leadership from the Government, all these are not likely to produce the desired objectives. Industries cannot be established on pious hopes and wishful thinking.

    At this juncture, I would quote the remarks made by the Member for Tanjong Pagar, leader of the People's Action Party, when he said:

    "No factory that has suffered a strike has shut down. No factory has decreased its production when a strike is resolved and the workers resume work."

Of this I can say the Member for Tanjong Pagar is ignorant. I would ask him to go to his own unions, the P.A.P.-Ied unions, and check up what has happened to the Hume Industries, the Gim Huat granite quarries of Jurong, the

Column: 121

Cressonite Industries, the Singapore Cold Storage, the Mis-Sino and the bus companies after the settlement of the strikes. The collections of the bus companies, after the settlement of a strike last year, in which I was one of the mediators, have dropped considerably. Can the Member for Tanjong Pagar explain why he made those remarks?

    The People's Action Party every now and then shout, "We stand for freedom!" But in actual fact the People's Action Party stand for destruction. I was in England during the Merdeka talks and many times the ex-Chief Minister decided to accept the half loaf which Britain had offered us, but the leader of the People's Action Party was egging him on and trying to ask him to demand the impossible, and therefore the talks failed completely. What did we get after all? Nothing. We returned empty-handed.

    It does appear to me that the Member for Tanjong Pagar is all the while trying to do his worst, particularly when he yesterday tried to decry the good work of my hon. Friend and Colleague the Member for Serangoon behind the smokescreen of a pseudo-Merdeka which the P.A.P. is always clamouring for.

    Government has indicated that the people are being encouraged to establish community centres on their own initiative. The present practice of the Government is to run and staff these community centres entirely by paid members of the Department of Social Welfare, and presumably by members of the Labour Front Party, with the assistance of -

    Mr Speaker: Order. Hon. Members must not make any imputations in their speeches.

    Mr William Tan: I am sorry, Sir. Will the Minister for Labour and Welfare see that this situation is put right immediately, that is, in accordance with the policy laid down by Government - that community centres must be solely run by people on their own initiative, duly assisted by paid staff from the Department of Social Welfare as and when necessary?

Column: 122



    In conclusion, I must warn the Government that if they display the same kind of weakness and confusion and, in some respects, the incompetence as they did during the last 17 months, they will seek in vain when they want our backing for their policy, but instead will encounter the most vigorous and sustained attack.

    Mr R. Jumabhoy (Telok Ayer): Mr Speaker, Sir, first I would like to congratulate one of my oldest colleagues in the Singapore Legislature, the Member for Havelock (Mr Lim Yew Hock), who has attained the highest position in this Colony as Chief Minister. Whilst congratulating him, I must say that I came prepared yesterday to vote against his motion as a matter of principle, but his speech completely disarmed me and the assurance which he has given that he will continue with his London talks in the near future has changed my mind and I am voting for his motion. On the other hand, Sir, the inaugural Address of His Excellency the Governor given on 29th August does not inspire much confidence when it says:

    "...continuity of policy and its plans for the future are linked with the achievements of the past 17 months."

    What are those achievements, Sir? 265 strikes of which the ex-Chief Minister was very proud. Riots. These things have completely shattered the economy of this little island. If that policy is to be continued, certainly I disagree.

    Sir, yesterday the Hon. the Chief Minister said that one Member always reminded him during the First Session about a minority of elected Members running the Government. I did so on principle, and I do so now on principle too. As one of the most senior Members in the Singapore Legislature after the war from the B.M.A. period, serving on the Advisory Council, the Legislative Council and now the Legislative Assembly, I think I am in a position to say a few words on the history of the past Legislatures. I am talking only of the post-war period. There were only official Members and nominated Members. Then in 1948 we had six elected

Column: 123

Members. The Government was run by an official majority. Then later on we had nine elected Members and four nominated Members and the world was told by the colonial power that here was an unofficial majority. But the four nominated Members frustrated whatever the elected Members would like to carry through. That was the Colonial Office policy.

    Now, Sir, we have gone further forward. We have 25 elected Members, four nominated Members and three ex-officio Members. But what is the use of those 25 elected Members if the voice of the majority of the elected Members is frustrated by the three ex-officios and the four nominated Members? It is no use having this constitution. It is a question of principle, therefore, when I say if any Party or any Independent Member wants to form a government, let him do so, but there should be a majority of elected Members on the Government side. That is quite logical. As I have said, it is no use having 25 elected Members in this Assembly when the voice of the elected majority can be frustrated. But, Sir, I am willing to support the present Government, whose term of office is very short because it is a caretaker Government and is in office only for the purpose of carrying on further negotiations in the Merdeka talks.

    Coming to His Excellency's Address, the emphasis is laid on trade. This small island is prosperous and I hope it will remain prosperous, because it only depends on trade. It has no natural resources of its own. I challenge anyone who can say it has. Rubber and tin are not ours; they are the Federation's. Singapore produces nothing. How is its population of a million and a quarter people going to exist? We are simply existing on the entrepot trade. First, I will deal with exports. We get goods from neighbouring countries, and these we grade and re-export. We live on that. Our labour lives on that. Our capital lives on that. In the case of imports, we get imports from various manufacturing countries and we

Column: 124

redistribute them to the neighbouring countries. We get handling charges. The middle man gets his commission. We exist on that. But can we do this always? We can only do this if our cost of living is cheaper, our wages are lower and we are satisfied with lower profits. Then we can exist, otherwise God alone knows what will happen.

    On the other hand, we require foreign capital. Countries like India, Indonesia and Ceylon always ask for foreign capital investment and they encourage it. When we say that we will nationalise our industry, the question arises: What can we nationalise in this small city? Where are we going to get our materials from? How are we going to finance it? We are too small for it. When you talk of the big countries, you must remember these factors - that they have their own natural resources; they have their own backing. We have none of these things. Only a stable government can inspire confidence, and only that confidence can attract foreign capital over here.
